plugin.name: LINCS
plugin.description: The LINCS tool provides for query and display of data generated by the Columbia LINCS Technology U01 and Computation U01 Centers, both under the direction of Dr. Andrea Califano. It provides experimental drug-drug synergy results, as well as computationally-derived similarity scores for drug mode of action. The NIH LINCS (Library of Integrated Network-based Cellular Signatures) Program supports a cellular-network-based investigation into biology at a number of centers across the country. It catalogs changes to gene expression and other cellular processes resulting from perturbation experiments.>br/> Data is preliminary, please see " here for currently available data.

plugin.name: Cellular Network Knowledge Base
plugin.description: The Cellular Networks Knowledge Base (CNKB) is a repository of molecular interactions, including ones both computationally and experimentally derived. Sources for interactions include both publicly available databases as well as reverse-engineered cellular context-specific regulatory interactomes developed in the lab of Dr. Andrea Califano at Columbia University. For parameter settings see the CNKB tutorial.

plugin.name: Gene Ontology
plugin.description: The Gene Ontology Enrichment component allows a list of e.g. differentially expressed genes to be characterized using the Gene Ontology terms annotated to them. It asks, whether for any particular GO term, the fraction of genes assigned to it in the "changed-gene" list is higher than expected by chance (is over-represented), relative to the fraction of genes assigned to that term in the reference set. The Gene Ontology analysis component in geWorkbench is built around the Ontologizer 2.0 software product from Peter Robinson's group at the Charite Medical Institute of the Humboldt University in Berlin. Please see the Gene Ontology tutorial for further details.

plugin.name: ANOVA
plugin.description: The geWorkbench ANOVA component implements a one-way analysis of variance calculation derived from TIGR's MeV (MultiExperiment Viewer). At least three sets of arrays must be specified. The ANOVA analysis returns any markers that show a significant expression difference across the array sets. For parameter settings see the ANOVA tutorial.

plugin.name: ARACNe
plugin.description: ARACNe (Algorithm for the Reconstruction of Accurate Cellular Networks) (Basso et al. 2005) is an information-theoretic algorithm used to identify transcriptional interactions between gene products using microarray gene expression profile data. Parameter settings see the ARACNe tutorial).

plugin.name: Cellular Network Knowledge Base
plugin.description: The Cellular Networks Knowledge Base (CNKB) is a repository of molecular interactions, including ones both computationally and experimentally derived. Sources for interactions include both publicly available databases as well as reverse-engineered cellular context-specific regulatory interactomes developed in the lab of Dr. Andrea Califano at Columbia University. For parameter settings see the CNKB tutorial.

plugin.name: Hierarchical Clustering
plugin.description: Hierarchical Clustering is a method to group arrays and/or markers together based on similarity on their expression profiles. geWorkbench implements its own code for agglomerative hierarchical clustering. Starting from individual points (the leaves of the tree), nearest neighbors are found for individual points, and then for groups of points, at each step building up a branched structure that converges toward a root that contains all points. The resulting graph tends to group similar items together. Several options for clustering method and metric are provided. For parameter settings see the Hierarchical Clustering tutorial.

plugin.name: MARINa(msVIPER)
plugin.description: The msViper implementation of MARINa (MAster Regulator INference algorithm) (Lim et al., 2009, Lefebvre et al., 2010) calculates whether the regulon of a transcription factor (TF) is enriched for genes that are differentially expressed between two classes of microarrays. The expression of the regulon genes (targets of the TF) serves as a proxy for the activity of the TF itself. TFs that are found to be differentially active are candidate master regulators of the phenotypic difference represented in the dataset. The user must supply a transcriptional network (e.g. reverse-engineered using ARACNe ) and a gene expression dataset. Please see the msViper tutorial).

plugin.name: Differential Expression (T-Test)
plugin.description: A t-Test analysis can be used to identify markers with statistically significant differential expression between two sets of microarrays (e.g. representing two different treatments or phenotypes). For parameter settings see the t-Test tutorial).

plugin.name: MarkUs
plugin.description: MarkUs (Fischer et al., 2011) is a web server which runs a variety of analyses to characterize the biochemical function of a provided protein structure. MarkUs identifies related protein structures and sequences, detects protein cavities, and calculates the surface electrostatic potentials and amino acid conservation profile. Parameter settings are identical to those used in the desktop version of the analysis (see the MarkUs tutorial).

plugin.name: GO Result Viewer
plugin.description: Gene Ontology Result Viewer.

plugin.name: PDB File Viewer
plugin.description: The PDB File Viewer provides a simple text viewer for PDB protein structure files.

plugin.name: Molecular Structure Viewer
plugin.description: Viewer for molecular structures .

plugin.name: Dendrogram plus heat map
plugin.description: The Dendrogram Viewer depicts the results from hierarchical clustering using a heatmap and dendrogram. See the Dendrogram Viewer section of the Hierarchical Clustering tutorial.

plugin.name: ANOVA Result Viewer
plugin.description: The ANOVA Result Viewer displays results in a spreadsheet format. The table columns are described in the Tabular Viewer section of the ANOVA tutorial.

plugin.name: Cytoscape
plugin.description: The Cytoscape Viewer depicts a gene network using Cytoscape Web, or using a plain text view for larger networks. â€œCytoscape-web is an open source software for the visualization of molecular networks being developed by a consortium of academic institutions. More information is available at the project web site

plugin.name: CNKB Result View
plugin.description: The result of a CNKB query is displayed in a table; a "throttle" allows the number of hits to be adjusted by significance. See the CNKB Results Viewer section of the CNKB tutorial.

plugin.name: MARINa(msVIPER) result viewer
plugin.description: The results of a MsViper analysis are shown in a table. The table columns are the same as those described for the desktop version of the analysis (see the MARINa (msViper) tutorial).

plugin.name: MarkUs Result Viewer
plugin.description: Displays the web page generated by the MarkUs service for functional protein structure analysis. See the MarkUs tutorial).

plugin.name: Tabular Microarray Viewer
plugin.description: Presents the matrix of expression measurements in a spreadsheet format. Each row represents an individual marker/probe and each column represents one sample/microarray.

plugin.name: T-test result viewer
plugin.description: The Volcano Plot graphs for each marker the t-test significance value vs the expression fold-change. See the t-Test Results section of the t-Test tutorial.

plugin.name: Aracne Preprocessing Result Viewer
plugin.description: The Aracne Preprocessing Result Viewer displays text configuration files.
